usage_tip: We use the Optative 'ვიცოდე' (That I may know) for the second half of 'I want to know'.
Active verb frame. The object 'გასაღები' takes the '-ს' suffix because it is the target.
'კარგავ' means you are in the process of losing it. Used for 'misplacing' items.
'პოულობს' implies the successful result of searching.
Idiom! Literally: 'We are losing the road/way' ('გზას').
'ფულს' is the object. 'პოულობთ' matches the plural 'You'.
Another idiom: 'Losing time' ('დროს') means wasting it.

english: Luka is finding a way out.
usage_tip: 'გამოსავალი' means 'Exit' or 'Solution'. Literally: 'The place to go out'.
'ვინც' is the relative pronoun 'Whoever'. A very common Georgian saying.

english: It is pointless, we are wasting time.
usage_tip: 'აზრი არ აქვს' literally means 'It has no opinion/meaning', used for 'It is pointless'.
'იმედი' (Hope) acts as the object. 'არ' goes immediately before the verb.

english: Sooner or later I will find it.
usage_tip: 'ვიპოვი' is the Future tense of finding. Note the root change from 'poulob' to 'povi'.
'როგორც იქნა' is a set phrase meaning 'Finally / As it happened'. 'ვიპოვე' is the Past tense.
'ვერ' implies ability: 'I am unable to find'. 'სათვალე' (Glasses) takes the '-ს'.
'დაკარგო' is the Optative/Command form. 'არ' is used for the prohibition.

english: If you look for it, you will find it.
usage_tip: 'მოძებნი' is the Future tense of 'Search'. 'იპოვი' is the Future tense of 'Find'.
Verbs ending in '-i' often describe a change of state happening to the subject.
'ემზადები' comes from 'მზად' (Ready). The 'ე-' prefix often signals 'getting/becoming'.
The subject remains in the simple Nominative case ('ის'), unlike the 'He feels cold' frame.
'ვემზადებით' implies active preparation (dressing, packing).
Plural 'You' adds the '-თ' ending.
'ისინი' matches the plural verb ending '-ებიან'.
Because this is a 'Process' verb, not an 'Inversion' verb, Mariam stays as 'Mariam-i'.
Technically Past tense (Aorist), but used to describe your current state: 'I have become tired'.
Compare: 'ვემზადები' (Process: I am preparing) vs 'მზად ვარ' (Result: I am ready).

english: I am getting more and more tired.
usage_tip: 'სულ უფრო და უფრო' emphasizes the progressive nature of the feeling.

english: I am getting ready to leave.
usage_tip: 'წასასვლელად' uses the Adverbial case to mean 'for the purpose of going'.

english: Don't worry, I am getting ready.
usage_tip: 'ღელვა' means 'To worry/agitate' (like waves). 'ნუ' is the polite 'Don't'.
Root is 'თბილი' (Warm). 'ვ-თბ-ებ-ი' means 'I am becoming warm'.
Root is 'ღამე' (Night). 'ღამდება' means 'It is becoming night'.
Root is 'ბრაზი' (Anger). The structure implies 'I am becoming angry'.
'შეიძლება' (It is possible) + Optative verb 'I enter'.
'მოვიზომო' is the specific verb for trying on clothes/sizes ('ზომა').
'დავჯდე' is the Optative form of sitting down. Polite and standard.
'ვნახო' comes from 'ნახვა' (To see). Used when asking to inspect something.
'გკითხოთ' tracks the 'You' (plural/polite) inside the verb with 'გ-'.
'წავიდეთ' is the Optative 'Let's go / That we go'.
'ითქვას' is the Passive voice: 'It might be said'. A sophisticated filler.
'თუ' (If) + 'შეიძლება' (Possible). Use this everywhere to be polite.
'არ შეიძლება' is stronger than 'No'. It means 'It is forbidden/impossible'.
Used to introduce a possibility. 'It is possible that he is late'.
Useful in crowds or when interrupting a conversation.
Reassuring someone that their request is okay.

english: Is it possible to pay by card?
usage_tip: 'გადახდა' is the noun 'Paying'. 'ბარათით' is 'With card' (Instrumental).
Literally: 'Is taking of a photo possible?'. 'გადაღება' is the verb noun.
Structure: 'Late that I call you, is it possible?'. 'რომ' connects the thought.

english: He said that he will come.
usage_tip: 'თქვა' is the Past tense (Aorist) of 'Say'. 'რომ' connects the speech to the quote.

english: They told me that you are here.
usage_tip: 'მითხრეს' implies 'They said to me'. The 'მ-' marks 'me'.

english: I know that you are right.
usage_tip: Active verb 'Know' + 'That' + Identity Frame.

english: I think that this is good.
usage_tip: 'მგონია' is an Inversion verb: 'It seems to me'. Use this for subjective thoughts.

english: By the way, they told me that...
usage_tip: 'სხვათა შორის' means 'Among others / By the way'. Great conversational bridge.

english: I am sure that everything will be fine.
georgian: დარწმუნებული ვარ, რომ ყველაფერი კარგად იქნება.
usage_tip: 'დარწმუნებული' means 'convinced/sure'. Literally: 'I am convinced that...'.

english: Apparently / As it seems, he is right.
usage_tip: 'როგორც ჩანს' is a fixed phrase meaning 'As it appears'. Note: we don't always need 'რომ' here.

english: The thing is that I don't know.
usage_tip: 'საქმე იმაშია' (The business is in that) is the standard way to say 'The point is...'.

english: I think that this is not enough.
georgian: ვფიქრობ, რომ ეს საკმარისი არ არის.
usage_tip: 'ვფიქრობ' is the active verb 'I think' (unlike 'Mgonia' which is 'It seems'). Use for logic.

english: They say that it will rain tomorrow.
usage_tip: 'ამბობენ' implies general hearsay or public knowledge.

english: I heard that you are going.
usage_tip: 'გავიგე' means both 'I understood' and 'I heard/found out'.

english: I hope that you will come.
usage_tip: Literally: 'I have hope that you will come'.

english: He asked me if I am ready.
usage_tip: 'თუ არა' (or not) is often added when reporting Yes/No questions.

english: I promised him that I would do it.
usage_tip: 'დავპირდი' means 'I promised'. The second verb often shifts to a 'conditional' future.

english: Do you know that he is not here?
georgian: იცი, რომ ის აქ არ არის?
usage_tip: Standard question format: [Active Verb] + [That] + [Fact].
'თურმე' (Apparently) matches the Perfect tense verb 'da-m-vickebia'.

english: Apparently you have seen this already.
usage_tip: 'უკვე' means 'already'. 'გინახავს' is the 'unwitnessed' or 'result' form of seeing.

english: He has apparently worked a lot.
usage_tip: Subject 'He' becomes 'Mas' (Dative) because in this tense, the person is the receiver.
'გვითქვამს' tracks 'Us'. 'ადრე-ც' means 'before-too'.

english: You guys have apparently bought it.
usage_tip: The verb implies 'I see the result of your buying' rather than watching the act itself.
'მათ' (Them) is Dative. 'გაუკეთებიათ' implies the job is finished and visible.

english: As it turned out, he wrote it.
usage_tip: 'გაირკვა' means 'It became clear'. 'დაუწერია' is the Perfect form of 'Wrote'.
Perfect tense is standard for discussing life experiences ('Have you ever...?').
Used when you see an empty chair, not when you watch him arrive late.
'მომხდარა' comes from 'khdoma' (happening). Used for historical facts.

english: It turns out Giorgi did it.
usage_tip: Giorgi takes the '-s' suffix because in the Perfect tense, the subject acts like a receiver.
'გიქნია' is the Perfect form of 'kena' (doing). Used for shock at a result.

english: Have you ever been to Georgia?
usage_tip: 'ყოფილხარ' is the Perfect form of 'To be'. Essential for 'Have you ever been' questions.

english: I have not thought about it.
usage_tip: 'მიფიქრია' is the result form of thinking. 'ამაზე' is 'On this'.
Exception! Sometimes we use imperfect forms with 'Thurme'. 'ვტყუოდი' means 'I was lying/wrong'.
Literally: 'I am you-on big'. '-ზე' handles the comparison logic.
'იმ-ზე' means 'On that'. 'უკეთესი' is the comparative form of Good ('კარგი').
'ჩაი' becomes 'ჩაი-ზე'. 'გემრიელი' implies deliciousness.
'პატარა' functions as both 'Small' and 'Younger/Smaller'.
'მათ-ზე' (On them). 'სწრაფად' is the adverb 'Fast'.

english: You guys know more than us.
usage_tip: 'მეტი' is 'More'. It is one of the most common comparative words.

english: This is more expensive than I thought.
usage_tip: 'ვიდრე' (Than) is used when comparing a noun to a verb phrase ('...than I thought').
'სჯობს' means 'It is better'. A classic saying.
'უფრო' is the auxiliary word used to make adjectives comparative (e.g., 'Upro kargi' = Better).
Literally: 'What is possible, more'. Used for requests.
'ყველაზე' (On all) creates the Superlative ('Most'). 'ყველაზე ლამაზი' = Most beautiful.
'ნაკლები' means 'Less'. 'არც' negates both sides.

english: I love you more than life.
usage_tip: 'სიცოცხლე' (Life) + '-ზე'. 'მეტად' is the adverb form of 'More'.

english: He is the tallest in the class.
usage_tip: 'ყველაზე მაღალი' = The tallest (Tall on everyone).
'ნაკლებად' (Less-ly) modifies the adjective 'საშიში' (Dangerous).

english: I am here to help you.
usage_tip: 'იმისთვის, რომ' is the connector for 'In order to'. It links your presence ('აქ ვარ') to the goal.

english: I study so that I may know.
usage_tip: The second verb 'ვიცოდე' is in the Optative mood, showing potentiality ('that I may know').

english: I need money to buy it.
usage_tip: Literally: 'Money is needed to me, for that, that I may buy ('ვიყიდო')'.

english: We work so that we may live.
usage_tip: 'ვიცხოვროთ' is the Optative form of 'Living'. The grammar links labor to survival.

english: I did this because I wanted to.
usage_tip: 'იმიტომ' (Therefore/For that reason) points back to the desire. A strong assertion of agency.

english: What is the reason for this?
usage_tip: 'მიზეზი' means Reason or Cause. 'ამის' is the Genitive 'Of this'.
'თავიდან აცილება' implies 'Avoiding'. The ending '-ად' shows the purpose.

english: Because of this we have problems.
usage_tip: 'გამო' acts like 'Due to'. It requires the target word to be in the Genitive case ('ამის').

english: That is precisely why I came.
usage_tip: 'სწორედ' intensifies the reason. Use this when your motive perfectly matches the situation.
'აქედან გამომდინარე' is a formal connector meaning 'Flowing out from here' (Consequently).
The goal is a state of being ('იყოს' - that it may be), not an action.

english: Tell me why you need it.
usage_tip: 'რისთვის' (For what) is often more specific than 'რატომ' (Why). It asks for the specific goal.
'ბოდიში მოვიხადო' is the formal phrase for apologizing. Literally: 'To take off the apology'.
Instead of the long 'იმისთვის, რომ', we use the 'Adverbial' case ('-ად') on the noun: 'For the seeing'.

english: He is saving money to buy a car.
usage_tip: Sometimes we drop 'იმისთვის' and just use 'რომ' (that) to indicate purpose, if context is clear.

english: If I have time, I will come.
usage_tip: 'მექნება' is the Future tense of 'Have'. 'თუ' sets the condition.
The simplest conditional frame. [If] + [Present Desire] + [Optative Action].

english: If our team wins, we will celebrate.
usage_tip: Both verbs are in the Future tense. 'ვიზეიმებთ' comes from 'ზეიმი' (celebration).

english: If I am not mistaken, it is so.
usage_tip: 'ვცდები' means 'I am erring / being mistaken'. A very common polite filler.
'შეიძლება' serves as the condition 'If it is possible'. 'დამეხმარეთ' is the plural/polite request.

english: If he doesn't come, I will leave.
usage_tip: Standard 'First Conditional' logic. Future + Future.

english: Even if that were the case.
usage_tip: 'რომ' here acts like 'even if'. 'იყოს' is the Optative 'be'.
'რა მოხდება' is the Future tense of 'What happens'. Essential for 'What if' scenarios.
'გავიგე' means 'I understood'. Use this before repeating what you think they said.
'შემთხვევა' means Case/Incident. Literally: 'In that case, if...'.
'აბა რა' is a very colloquial Georgian phrase for 'Of course / What else!'.

english: If it is necessary, I will do it.
usage_tip: 'საჭიროა' (It is necessary) is the condition. The result is a simple Future action.

english: If you ask me, it's not good.
usage_tip: 'მკითხავ' tracks 'me' with the 'მ-' prefix. 'არ ვარგა' means 'It's no good / worthless'.

english: If it rains, we stay home.
usage_tip: 'იწვიმებს' is the future tense 'It will rain'. 'დავრჩებით' is 'We will stay'.

english: Whatever happens, I am with you.
georgian: რაც არ უნდა მოხდეს, შენთან ვარ.
usage_tip: 'რაც არ უნდა' implies 'No matter what'. 'მოხდეს' is the Optative 'happen'.
The verb 'ვიყიდე' (I bought) transforms into 'გიყიდე' to include 'You' as the beneficiary.
The marker 'მი-' shows the action was done for 'me'.
Subject 'მან' takes the heavy Ergative case. The marker 'უ-' points to a 3rd person receiver.
'მათ' (Them) is the receiver. 'ვ-უ-ყიდეთ' shows 'We' (ვ-) did it for 'him/them' (უ-).

english: You guys bought this for us.
usage_tip: The marker 'გვი-' is specific to 'for us'. It fits right before the verb root.

english: They bought this for the child.
usage_tip: The recipient 'ბავშვს' is marked with the Dative case ('-ს'). The verb uses 'უ-' to point to him.
Subject: 'გიორგიმ'. Recipient: 'მარიამს'. Verb: 'გაუკეთა' (Did it for her).

english: I want to say thank you to you.
usage_tip: 'გადაგიხადოთ' means 'to pay you'. The 'გი-' makes it directed at 'you'.
Here we use the Postposition 'თვის' (For) instead of the verb marker. Both are correct.

english: Of course I will do it for you.
usage_tip: 'გაგიკეთებ' uses the Future tense with the 'გი-' marker. 'I will do it for you'.

english: I am not planning anything against you.
usage_tip: Usually 'გიპირებ' means 'I plan for you', but context implies negative intent here.

english: I will return it to you.
usage_tip: 'დაბრუნება' is return. 'და-გი-ბრუნებ' means 'I will return it for/to you'.

english: He built a house for himself.
usage_tip: 'აიშენა' uses the 'ი-' marker which means 'For oneself'. 'თავისთვის' reinforces 'for self'.

english: Can you open the door for me?
usage_tip: 'გამიღე' (Open for me) implies the beneficiary is 'me' (the 'მ-' marker is hidden/assimilated).

english: I am writing you a letter.
usage_tip: 'გწერ' (I write you) includes the object 'you' inside the verb (via 'გ-').
The prefix 'ა-' indicates upward motion. The root verb is 'სვლა' (motion).
The prefix 'ჩა-' indicates motion downwards, often into a container or enclosed space.
'ბრუნდება' is a reflexive verb meaning 'He turns himself back'.

english: We are going up the stairs.
usage_tip: 'კიბე' means stairs/ladder. Note we use '-ზე' (on) because we step *on* them.
The verb matches the plural 'თქვენ' ending '-ებით'.

context: Waiting at the bottom of the hill.
usage_tip: 'ჩამო-' is a compound prefix: 'ჩა-' (down) + 'მო-' (towards me).
We use 'down-come' for arriving from another city or country, implying landing or settling.
'უკან' literally means 'behind' or 'back'. 'მოვიდა' is the simple past 'He came'.
Idiom! Literally: 'Heart snapped/broke to me'. Used for deep disappointment.
Imperative command. The verb is shortened to just the prefix and root.
Used when telling someone to pass by a location on their way down.
Past tense (Aorist). The 'და-' prefix shows the action is completed.
'ადით' is the plural/polite command form of 'Go up'.
We use the same verb for the sun setting as for a person going downstairs.

english: He went up and then came down.
usage_tip: Contrasting 'ა-' (away/up) and 'ჩამო-' (toward/down).
'მოვახერხე' implies overcoming an obstacle to achieve the result.

context: Phone call to a late friend.
usage_tip: The action 'მოსვლა' (Coming) is treated as the object of 'Managed'.
Because this is the Past tense (Aorist), the subject 'მან' is in the Ergative case.
'ყველაფერი' (Everything) is the object. 'მოვახერხეთ' matches 'We'.

english: Were you guys able to do this?
usage_tip: 'შეძელით' is the past tense of 'Can' (Ability). It implies 'Did you find the power?'.
'ვერ' indicates inability despite trying. 'მათ' is the Ergative plural subject.

english: It wasn't possible to save him.
usage_tip: 'მოხერხდა' is the passive voice: 'It was not managed'. 'გადარჩენა' is 'Saving'.
'როგორმე' means 'somehow' or 'in some way'.
'ბოლოს და ბოლოს' means 'At the end of ends' (Finally).

english: Of course he will manage it.
usage_tip: 'მოახერხებს' is the Future tense. The subject returns to the base form.

english: I couldn't manage by any means.
usage_tip: 'ვერაფრით' means 'by no means / with nothing'. Double negation is standard.
'როგორ' (How) asks for the method of success.

english: If you try, you will manage.
usage_tip: 'ეცდები' is the future of 'Try'. Condition + Result.

english: I tried, but I couldn't manage.
usage_tip: 'ვეცადე' is the past tense 'I tried'. 'მაგრამ' connects the contrast.

english: I managed to do it on time.
usage_tip: 'დროულად' is the adverb 'Timely / On time'.
The suffix '-ულია' creates the Past Passive Participle (State of being done).
'დაკეტილი' comes from the verb 'კეტავს' (He closes). It describes the current state.
'ღია' describes the state of openness. Not to be confused with the action 'Opening'.
'მზად' is an indeclinable word meaning 'Ready'. We attach 'არის' (is).
'დალეული' means 'Drunk up'. The action is finished, and this is the result.
'ნათქვამი' comes from 'თქმა' (Saying). 'It is said'.
Idiom: 'With this, everything is said'.
'დაწერილი' describes the state of text existing on paper.
'დარწმუნებული' (Convinced) acts like an adjective describing the speaker.
'გასაკვირი' means 'Surprising thing'. The '-ც' adds 'even'.
Literally: 'I have it heard'. This is the Perfect construction using a participle.
'გადაწყვეტილი' comes from the verb 'Decide'. The matter is closed.
'გატეხილი' comes from 'Breaking'. It describes the object's condition.
'დაკავებული' means 'Occupied / Taken / Busy'.
'დაგეგმილი' comes from 'გეგმა' (Plan).
'რაც არ უნდა' + Optative Verb is the formula for 'No matter what X'.
'ვინც' means 'Whoever'. 'იყოს' is the Optative 'Be'.
'სადაც' means 'Where' + 'ever'. 'წახვიდე' is the Optative 'You go'.
'როგორც' means 'How / As'. Used to show method doesn't matter.
Even if it is surprising, the fact remains.

georgian: რაც არ უნდა მოხდეს, მე აქ ვარ.
usage_tip: Combining the 'Whatever' frame with the 'Location' frame.
'როგორიც' refers to the quality or type ('What kind of').

english: With all the might I have.
usage_tip: Idiom. 'ძალი' and 'ღონე' both mean power/strength.
Literally: 'What is possible, soon'.
Literally: 'What is the main thing...'.
Simple statement of accepting reality.
Traditional fairy tale opener. Lit: 'There was, and there was not, what?'.
'რაც გინდა' (What you want) acts as the object of 'Do'.

english: Whoever calls, tell them I'm not here.
georgian: ვინც არ უნდა დარეკოს, უთხარი, რომ არ ვარ.
usage_tip: Complex sentence: [Whoever calls] + [Tell them] + [That I am not].

english: However hard it is, I will do it.
georgian: რაც არ უნდა რთული იყოს, გავაკეთებ.
usage_tip: [No matter how hard be] + [I will do].
'აკეთებ' (Doing) becomes 'გა-აკეთებ'. 'ხვალ' (Tomorrow) is the trigger.
'წერს' (Writing) becomes 'და-წერს'. Subject 'ის' stays plain.
'ვიყიდით' (We buy) implies the future by itself in this context, or adds 'შე-'/ 'ი-' prefixes.
'ნახავ' is the Future of 'Seeing'. Object is implied.
'დაგვეხმარებიან' uses the 'და-' prefix to mark the future.
'ვიტყვი' is the future of 'Saying'. Irregular verb change.
'ამზადებს' (Prepares) becomes 'მო-ამზადებს'. 'სადილს' is the object.
'სვამთ' (Drink) changes root to 'დალევთ' in the future.
'ვსწავლობ' (I study) becomes 'ვი-სწავლი' (I will learn).
'იხდიან' (Paying) becomes 'გადა-იხდიან'.
Subject 'გიორგი' is plain. Object 'მანქანას' takes **-ს**.
'ვრეკავ' (Calling) becomes 'და-გირეკავ'.
